appearances.snippet: joining us now is democratic senator jon ossoff of georgia. senate intelligence committee, the senate rules committee. he's running for reelection this year. senator ossoff, you your candidacy, your candidacy now is suffering from what i know candidates like you worry about. and that is other people's confidence that you are going to win. but but i think you you have to recognize what we are seeing nationwide here on the issues, what we've seen in the elections this year. and now when we see a strong democratic candidate emerging in alaska, not only is there some confidence that you're going to win, but there is a building possibility toward confidence that the democrats could win back the senate. >> lawrence, thank you for having me. and here's how to look at it. we have huge momentum because this president and his agenda and his enablers in congress are massively unpopular. they have been stripping the country bare and selling the spare parts to enrich themselves and their wealthy donors. people are hurting. people are hurting because their

appearances.snippet: toss ups, with the most vulnerable candidates being republican susan collins in maine and democrat jon ossoff's bring in two. longtime campaign strategist mark mckinnon is the former adviser to george w bush and john mccain, and creator of the documentary series the circus. and back with us is chuck rocha, a democratic strategist who served as senior advisor to bernie sanders presidential campaign. thanks to both of you. mark, what race are you most interested in? >> well, first of all, i'll say that it's, you know, historically, the the party that holds the presidency loses the house only twice in modern politics has has that changed the equation. so that's unlikely to happen. so democrats are likely to win the house. the average pickup is 25 seats and they only need to pick up four as you just mentioned. so very likely the house will flip. the question is can the republicans hold the senate? and the answer is likely yes, but but there's some very interesting races. the the north carolina race is very interesting where democrats could flip that because they have a very popular former governo

appearances.snippet: whereas jon ossoff, the democrat in georgia, is the only democrat up for reelection in a state obviouslyhat donald trump won, but there are open contests in true battleground states where donald trump was successful just a year ago. a place like michigan is a perfect example of that. so north carolina is another one. so there are some key contests. i just don't know if the map will get big enough. this gets back to your question about the wave. if there's a big anti-trump democratic wave that could potentially put democrats over the top in the senate, but it's just going to be a much tougher climb for. >> them, we have to look towards january 30th because that's when the government is funded until. right? i mean could we see another government shutdown? >> potentially, yes. and i am fascinated by this because if you would have told me that the minority in the house, the democrats would be able to control the state of play through that shutdown and into these closing days of the year, on the battle for health care and the like, i would have said, i'll be very surprised if that's the case,
